title: CMEC secures $545 million loan -- via EPC+F agreement -- with TALCO for Aluminum Smelter Modernization Project
description: On April 15, 2019, Talco Aluminium Company (TALCO) — a state-owned enterprise (SOE) in Tajikistan—signed a $545 million engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) plus finance (EPC+F) contract with China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) for an Aluminum Smelter Modernization Project (also known as the TALCO 300kt/a Electrolytic Aluminum Production Line Rehabilitation Project). The agreement was only to become effective upon the satisfaction of certain conditions precedent. On November 1, 2019, the Government oof Tajikistan issued a decree, converting TALCO from an SOE (or so-called ‘state unitary enterprise’) into an open joint-stock company and effectively allowing for its (partial) privatization. Then, on December 4, 2019, Radio Liberty’s Tajik Service quoted China’s former ambassador to Tajikistan, Yue Bin, as saying that CMEC would purchase an ownership stake in TALCO in return for the Chinese company investing $545 million. Yue offered no details about the size of any ownership stake to be sold and TALCO has not commented publicly on the prospect of it being partially privatized. However, the conditions for its sale were created. Then, in May 2020, the Government of Tajikistan approved the EPC+F (loan) agreement.   The purpose of the project is to modernize TALCO’s aluminum smelter in the town of Tursunzoda. The project scope includes rehabilitation of TALCO’s existing production line electrolytic aluminum series and ancillary facilities. CMEC is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. It is responsible for the design and optimization, procurement of equipment, civil engineering and construction, installation, training, commissioning, warranty and other works of the project. The project’s construction period is 24 months and it includes two phases; each phase will last for 12 months upon commencement of construction.   CMEC and Global Advanced Manufacturing Institute (GAMI) are the contractors responsible for project design and implementation. As of May 2023, GAMI was undertaking a project feasibility study.   According to a World Bank-IMF Debt Sustainability Analysis (DSA) that was published in May 2020, ‘[t]he Ministry of Finance [of Tajikistan] does not record non-guaranteed debt of SOEs. In 2019, TALCO, a loss-making state-owned aluminum company, was allowed to borrow without a government guarantee. Subsequently, TALCO has signed a MOU to borrow $545 million from China to modernize its plant. The finalization of contract and associated disbursement are expected in 2020.’ The IMF also warned that the $545 million loan presents a substantial contingent liability risk, as it is non-guaranteed SOE debt worth 6.5% of Tajikistan’s GDP.
staff_comments: 1. Under most EPC+F contractual arrangements, a loan is extended to the EPC contractor but with a sovereign guarantee from the host government. Therefore, AidData assumes that the loan issued to CMEC is backed by a repayment guarantee from the Government of Tajikistan (i.e. a sovereign guarantee).2. The Chinese project title is 塔吉克300kt/a电解铝技改项目 or 塔吉克斯坦共和國塔吉克300kt/a電解鋁技改項目.3. Global Advanced Manufacturing Institute (GAMI) was established in China in 2008 by wbk Institute of Production Science of the Karlsruhe Institute of Technology (KIT). KIT is one of the first technical universities in Germany and worldwide known for its high-quality education and research.
combined_text:
# Sector
INDUSTRY, MINING, CONSTRUCTION

# Title
CMEC secures $545 million loan -- via EPC+F agreement -- with TALCO for Aluminum Smelter Modernization Project

# Description
On April 15, 2019, Talco Aluminium Company (TALCO) — a state-owned enterprise (SOE) in Tajikistan—signed a $545 million engineering, procurement and construction (EPC) plus finance (EPC+F) contract with China Machinery Engineering Corporation (CMEC) for an Aluminum Smelter Modernization Project (also known as the TALCO 300kt/a Electrolytic Aluminum Production Line Rehabilitation Project). The agreement was only to become effective upon the satisfaction of certain conditions precedent. On November 1, 2019, the Government oof Tajikistan issued a decree, converting TALCO from an SOE (or so-called ‘state unitary enterprise’) into an open joint-stock company and effectively allowing for its (partial) privatization. Then, on December 4, 2019, Radio Liberty’s Tajik Service quoted China’s former ambassador to Tajikistan, Yue Bin, as saying that CMEC would purchase an ownership stake in TALCO in return for the Chinese company investing $545 million. Yue offered no details about the size of any ownership stake to be sold and TALCO has not commented publicly on the prospect of it being partially privatized. However, the conditions for its sale were created. Then, in May 2020, the Government of Tajikistan approved the EPC+F (loan) agreement.   The purpose of the project is to modernize TALCO’s aluminum smelter in the town of Tursunzoda. The project scope includes rehabilitation of TALCO’s existing production line electrolytic aluminum series and ancillary facilities. CMEC is the EPC contractor responsible for project implementation. It is responsible for the design and optimization, procurement of equipment, civil engineering and construction, installation, training, commissioning, warranty and other works of the project. The project’s construction period is 24 months and it includes two phases; each phase will last for 12 months upon commencement of construction.   CMEC and Global Advanced Manufacturing Institute (GAMI) are the contractors responsible for project design and implementation. As of May 2023, GAMI was undertaking a project feasibility study.   According to a World Bank-IMF Debt Sustainability Analysis (DSA) that was published in May 2020, ‘[t]he Ministry of Finance [of Tajikistan] does not record non-guaranteed debt of SOEs. In 2019, TALCO, a loss-making state-owned aluminum company, was allowed to borrow without a government guarantee. Subsequently, TALCO has signed a MOU to borrow $545 million from China to modernize its plant. The finalization of contract and associated disbursement are expected in 2020.’ The IMF also warned that the $545 million loan presents a substantial contingent liability risk, as it is non-guaranteed SOE debt worth 6.5% of Tajikistan’s GDP.
justification: Modernization of aluminum smelter with focus on rehabilitation and optimization, likely including energy efficiency improvements
evidence: Rehabilitation of existing production line electrolytic aluminum series and ancillary facilities, project includes design and optimization

title: Chinese Government donates first batch of anti-pandemic materials to the government of Tajikistan for COVID-19 prevention
description: On March 30, 2020, the Chinese Government donated anti-COVID-19 materials to the Tajikistan Ministry of Health and Social Protection during a handover ceremony.  The donation consisted of 2,000 COVID-19 tests, 1,000 medical protective coveralls, 500 non-contact thermometers, 1,000 eyeglasses, 1,000 pairs of disposable medical gloves, and 1,000 pairs of disposable medical overshoes.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Government donates first batch of anti-pandemic materials to the government of Tajikistan for COVID-19 prevention

# Description
On March 30, 2020, the Chinese Government donated anti-COVID-19 materials to the Tajikistan Ministry of Health and Social Protection during a handover ceremony.  The donation consisted of 2,000 COVID-19 tests, 1,000 medical protective coveralls, 500 non-contact thermometers, 1,000 eyeglasses, 1,000 pairs of disposable medical gloves, and 1,000 pairs of disposable medical overshoes.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare and pandemic response with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of medical supplies for COVID-19 prevention, including tests, protective equipment, and medical supplies

title: Chinese Government sends medical team to Dushanbe, Tajikistan in May 2020
description: On May 24, 2020, a medical team of 14 Chinese doctors arrived arrived at Dushanbe International Airport to provide pandemic-related advice and experience to doctors in Tajikistan. In particular, the team instructed local critical care doctors on COVID-19 treatment strategies. The team was stationed in Dushanbe for the duration of their campaign. The medical team stayed in Tajikistan for 9 days.  Liu Bin, Ambassador to Tajikistan, First Deputy Minister of Health of Tajikistan Umar Zoda, Deputy Minister of Foreign Affairs Hussein Zoda, and the Deputy Mayor of Dushanbe, were present at the ceremony. In May 2020, the medical team was presented an award for their service by the Shaanxi Provincial Committee of the Communist Youth League and the Shaanxi Provincial Youth Federation.

title: Chinese Government donates third batch of anti-pandemic materials to Tajikistan in June 2020
description: On June 17, 2020, the Chinese Government held a handover ceremony for the donation of a third batch of COVID-19 aid to the Government of Tajikistan. The donation consisted of 50,000 test kits, 20,000 protective clothing articles, 50,000 N95 masks, and 500,000 medical surgical masks, totaling 9.4 tons and 731 boxes. The monetary value of the donation is unknown.  The exchange occurred at the Karasu Port on the border between China and Tajikistan on June 17.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.

title: Chinese Government donates the second batch of anti-pandemic materials to Tajikistan in May 2020
description: On May 6, 2020, the Chinese Government donated a second batch of anti-COVID-19 materials to the Government of Tajikistan. The donation consisted of 50,000 COVID-19 reagent tests, 30,000 pieces of medical protective clothing, 10,000 medical N95 masks, 150,000 medical surgical masks, 30,000 medical isolation goggles, 50,000 pairs of medical gloves, and 1,000 infrared thermometers.   The handover took place at Karasu Port on the China-Tajikistan border.

title: Xinjiang Uyghur Autonomous Region in China donated anti-pandemic materials to the Government of Tajikistan (Linked to Project #94745)

The donation consisted of 20,000 disposable medical masks, 2,000 KN95 masks, 2,000 pairs of medical gloves, 250 sets of medical protective shields, and 100 infrared thermometers. This donation accompanied a videoconference with health experts in Tajikistan to discuss COVID-19 (Project #94745).

title: Chinese Ministry of Defense donated RMB 2 million of anti-COVID-19 supplies to the Tajikistan Ministry of Defense
description: On May 13, 2020, the Chinese Ministry of Defense donated anti-COVID-19 materials to the Tajikistan Ministry of Defense. The donation consisted of 50 ventilators, 220,000 disposable medical masks, 500 laser thermometers, 10,000 medical protective suits, 1,000 pairs of protective glasses, 14,000 large packs of hydroxychloroquine sulfate tablets, and other protective equipment. The donation was valued at RMB 2 million, according to the Embassy of the People's Republic of China in the Republic of Tajikistan.

title: Chinese Ministry of Agriculture and Yangling Modern Agriculture International Cooperation Co., Ltd donated anti-COVID-19 materials to the Ministry of Agriculture of Tajikistan
description: On April 7, 2020, a handover ceremony was held for the donation of anti-COVID-19 supplies from the Chinese Ministry of Agriculture and Yangling Modern Agriculture International Cooperation Co., Ltd to the Tajikistan Ministry of Agriculture. The monetary value of the donation is unknown. This donation represents part of a package grant to seven SCO member states including Uzbekistan, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, Pakistan, and India.

title: The Chinese government sent 250 experts to Tajikistan to implement various construction projects
description: On August 3, 2020, the Minister of Economic Development and Trade of Tajikistan announced that China would be sending 250 specialists to assist in various Chinese-backed construction projects in the country. The projects included a Tajik parliament and government complex in Dushanbe (Project ID# 71727, 53786), rehabilitation of roads in Bokhtar (currently Kushoniyon) and Kulob districts (Project ID# 72612,71741, #90579, #53990), the project on rehabilitation of the Kulob-Muminobod road and preparations for the second phase of Dushanbe-Kulob-Khorog-Kulma highway rehabilitation project (Project ID# 72612, 71741, #90579, #53990), which includes rehabilitation of the Darvoz-Vanj section of the highway. The specialists were expected to arrive in early August.
combined_text:
# Sector
RECONSTRUCTION RELIEF AND REHABILITATION

# Title
The Chinese government sent 250 experts to Tajikistan to implement various construction projects

# Description
On August 3, 2020, the Minister of Economic Development and Trade of Tajikistan announced that China would be sending 250 specialists to assist in various Chinese-backed construction projects in the country. The projects included a Tajik parliament and government complex in Dushanbe (Project ID# 71727, 53786), rehabilitation of roads in Bokhtar (currently Kushoniyon) and Kulob districts (Project ID# 72612,71741, #90579, #53990), the project on rehabilitation of the Kulob-Muminobod road and preparations for the second phase of Dushanbe-Kulob-Khorog-Kulma highway rehabilitation project (Project ID# 72612, 71741, #90579, #53990), which includes rehabilitation of the Darvoz-Vanj section of the highway. The specialists were expected to arrive in early August.
justification: Projects focus on general infrastructure development and rehabilitation without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Construction of government complex, road rehabilitation projects, highway rehabilitation projects
